title: Master Thesis: Exploring the Reliability of EEG and Eye-Tracking for Biometric Authentication
description: Explored reliability of EEG and eye-tracking signals for biometric authentication; compared unimodal and multimodal approaches for their strengths, limitations, and benefits.
description2: This thesis investigates the effectiveness of electroencephalography (EEG) and eye-tracking data, individually and in combination, for biometric user authentication. Using the EEGEyeNet dataset, which contains both EEG and eye-tracking recordings, the original eye-movement prediction task was restructured to focus on identity detection. A range of classical machine learning (ML) models and deep learning (DL) architectures were evaluated under both minimally and maximally preprocessed conditions, and implemented in both PyTorch and TensorFlow to ensure framework consistency. The results demonstrate that simple ML models such as Gaussian Naive Bayes (GaussianNB) and k-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) consistently outperformed more complex models, including support vector machines (SVMs) and DL networks, in terms of both accuracy and computational efficiency. Surprisingly, models trained on minimally preprocessed data yielded better performance than those using heavily cleaned signals, suggesting that aggressive artifact removal can eliminate identity-relevant information. Notably, combining EEG and eye-tracking features led to significant performance gains, highlighting the value of multimodal approaches for capturing robust biometric signatures. These findings underscore the potential of lightweight ML classifiers for real-time, resource-constrained biometric systems and emphasize the importance of preserving signal diversity during preprocessing. The study also raises questions about the scalability of current models and the need for fine-tuned DL architectures in future multimodal systems. Overall, this work provides practical insights into model selection, preprocessing strategies, and system design for physiology-based biometric authentication.
achievements: Implemented and benchmarked a spectrum of ML and DL models: GaussianNB, KNN, SVM, Linear/Ridge Regression, Lasso, ElasticNet, GradientBoost, AdaBoost, XGBoost
Prototyped and tested several DL architectures: CNN, EEGNet, InceptionTime, PyramidalCNN, Xception in both PyTorch and TensorFlow
Benchmarked unimodal (EEG or eye-tracking) vs. multimodal (combined) systems
Demonstrated that lightweight ML models (GaussianNB, KNN) can outperform SVMs and DL in both accuracy and efficiency for identity detection
Showed that minimal preprocessing on raw signals improves model performance over heavily cleaned data
Highlighted the importance of preserving data diversity in physiological biometrics preprocessing
Discussed implications for scalable, real-time, resource-constrained biometric authentication systems

title: 3D Geometry Reconstruction with NeRF
description: Built NeRF-based pipelines for 3D reconstruction; integrated PyTorch3D, Open3D, and Chamfer Distance evaluation.
achievements: Generated meshes from radiance fields and depth cues
Compared implicit vs. explicit rendering trade-offs

title: AI-driven Healthy Habits App for Children
description: Mobile app with customizable avatars, activity tracking, and gamification; validated with participatory design.
achievements: Designed and tested with user feedback

title: Norwegian Psychology Support Bot (Meta Hackathon)
description: Built an LLM-powered assistant using Llama for Norwegian real-time advice; presented at Meta Hackathon (Feb 2025).
achievements: Prototype demonstrating AI mental health support
Collaborated with Meta, Cerebral Valley, and Nebius AI
Used prompt engineering with Llama for Norwegian language support

title: News Classification with OpenAI
description: Classifying news articles into categories using OpenAI's API.
description2: This project is a simple example of how to use OpenAI's API to classify news articles into different categories. This was originally a case assiagnment for a job interview. My code devides the whole article into paragraphs, each paragraph has a different topic, and the models reads each paragraph to classify the article into the correct category.
achievements: Classified news articles into different categories
Used prompt engineering with OpenAI's gpt-4o-mini

title: Medical Imaging Super-Resolution
description: Implemented ESRGAN and EDSR super-resolution models for pathology images to enhance diagnostic quality, using BCI dataset.
achievements: Improved resolution and visual quality for analysis

title: Evolutionary Algorithms for Optimization Problems
description: Implemented Genetic Algorithms, Particle Swarm Optimization, and Ant Colony Optimization to tackle classical problems like the N-Queen puzzle and the Traveling Salesman Problem, exploring computational efficiency in AI-driven solutions.
description2: Project at OsloMet â€“ Oslo Metropolitan University. Investigated various evolutionary algorithms and their applications to solve combinatorial optimization tasks. Explored solution quality and runtime trade-offs for Genetic Algorithm (GA), Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), and Ant Colony Optimization (ACO).
achievements: Evaluated computational efficiency and performance on N-Queen and TSP
Explored solution quality versus runtime trade-offs
